subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 1676
msgSnippet: ... Well, OK, but what makes private automatically better than protected? I have to put some word there. What harm does it do to say protected, or even public?
messageBody:
On Monday, October 31, 2005, at 7:45:36 AM, Elliotte wrote:

> Basic Agile: You Ain't Going to Need It (YAGNI). Why make the effort to
> create a protected method that more than likely will never be used or
> will be used so rarely it won't even pay back the complexity cost of the
> extra JavaDoc? Designing for subclassing is hard. It takes roughly three
> times as much effort as designing a final class, maybe more. Most
> non-final classes in the wild are fundamentally broken. Of course
> sometimes you do need subclasses, but don't go adding extension points
> willy-nilly until you're ready to design them properly, document them
> fully, consider their implications for other dependent methods, and do
> all the other hard work required to create a truly extensible class.
> Java erred by not making final the default, but there's no reason we
> have to repeat its mistakes.

Well, OK, but what makes private automatically better than
protected? I have to put some word there. What harm does it do to
say protected, or even public?

I answer that it depends a great deal on what the code is trying to
be. If a bunch of us are writing some application in XP style, then
why not leave it wide open? No harm is likely to come from it.

On the other hand, if we're publishing a library, then more privacy
and more thinking is probably called for.

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
Ron gave me a good suggestion once. -- Carlton (banshee858)
